data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Here’s the reference in the 26th September RNS The Group expects further growth in the money transfer business with such growth expected to be fuelled by strategic partnerships and market diversification. “While development using SWIFT network is still underway, new collaborations with bKash (i.e, the biggest mobile financial services provider in Bangladesh) and Mastercard Send, which is expected to go live in the next few months, will enhance the Group's product offerings, enabling faster and more secure cross-border transactions.” Additionally, the Group has initiated incoming remittance services to Somalia, tapping into underserved markets and broadening its global reach. These initiatives are expected to drive revenue growth.”

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Very good point, Warrie  honestly didn’t even cross my mind about the wortk ethic. I’ve just gone back through a few RNSs this evening and I actually think we’re due another announcement fairly soon around Mastercard Send. It’s mentioned alongside bKash in the half year, so it feels like the next logical step? When you look at the recent bKash news in that context, it starts to make a lot more sense especially when you remember we’re doing £230 million in revenue and still losing money. That tells you straight away the issue here isn’t scale, it’s margin mix. The legacy business around airtime reloads and bill payments does huge volume, but at very thin margins, and to be fair the Board has been pretty open about that. Where it gets interesting now is what’s now being layered on top. bKash isn’t a concept or a pilot as shared in my original post, expats sent remittances more than five million times, settled instantly via Pubali. That corridor now runs 24/7, 365. The behaviour is already there and it’s trusted, it’s repeat usage at scale, and as you mentioned, the working patterns and hours are very different to what most people are used to in the UK. We’re not trying to invent demand here. We’re plugging into an ecosystem where remittance is frequent, digital and increasingly stays inside the wallet for bills, payments and services which is exactly where fee income and FX margin live! The Board has been clear that remittance revenues will be “relatively modest”, and that makes total sense against a £230m revenue base. But the point isn’t headline growth anymore, it’s quality. At this scale, even a small improvement in blended margin has an outsized impact and roughly speaking, a 1% uplift in margin is worth north of £2 million The strategy explicitly references Mastercard Send still to come. That’s not name dropping or hype. it’s better infrastructure with faster settlement, broader corridor reach, lower friction and better transaction velocity. You don’t add that unless the volumes already justify it, and in this case we  clearly do. The real question now is whether the economics on flows we already have can be steadily improved. If they can we just need better rails on existing, and very soon expanding, transaction volumes! Bodes well for the SPAC listing!

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Bangladeshi expatriates have sent remittances to local bKash accounts more than five million times within 10 months via Pubali Bank. This hassle-free and secure service, offered by the mobile financial service (MFS) provider bKash, has earned the trust of expatriates and their families, encouraging sending remittances through legal channels, strengthening the country’s foreign currency reserves. Recently, a ceremony was held at bKash’s headquarters to celebrate this achievement where Pubali Bank’s Managing Director and CEO Mohammad Ali and bKash’s CEO Kamal Quadir, along with senior officials from both organisations were present. They highlighted the significance of this joint service and pledged to make remittance services even easier and safer for users. As a vital lifeline for the country's economy, these hard-earned remittances from expatriates are boosting the country's foreign exchange reserves and contributing to macroeconomic stability. To facilitate this, Pubali Bank and bKash have created a robust ecosystem for expatriates, to send remittances easily and securely. Currently, expatriates from 33 countries can send remittances through 11 international Money Transfer Operators (MTOs), which are settled instantly in the recipient's bKash account through Pubali Bank. Besides, recipients receive a government incentive of Tk 25 per thousand. They can easily cash out the remittance from nearby bKash agent points. Moreover, Families of the expatriates can utilise remittance to take various services through their bKash accounts, including paying for products and services, utility bills (gas, electricity, water), sending money, mobile recharge, paying educational and government fees, donations, insurance premiums, microfinance payments and many other services from the comfort of their homes. In addition to offering convenient, instant and secure remittance transfers, bKash has lowered cash-out fees. Beneficiaries can now withdraw remittances at a minimal cost of Tk 7 per thousand from approximately 2,500 ATMs of 19 leading commercial banks. December 2025 https://unb.com.bd/category/Press%20Releases/expats-send-remittance-over-5m-times-to-bkash-via-pubali-bank-in-10-month/174301

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: Key Factors for MBO collaboration with bKash: • The "Digital Conversion" Upside: Currently, over 40% of outward remittances from Malaysia are digital. MBO is targeting the remaining 60% who still use cash. • Network Synergy: bKash recently (Feb 2026) signed a deal with Pubali Bank for 24/7 automated cash management. While independent of MBO, this strengthens the bKash ecosystem's liquidity, making the "receiving" end more attractive for MBO's customers. • User Base: With ~900,000 Bangladeshi permit holders in Malaysia, even capturing a 5–10% market share of this specific corridor would represent a significant volume for a company of MBO's size (Market Cap ~£6m). Since the service launches on Feb 15, the first meaningful data on transaction volumes will likely start appearing in quarterly updates around May or June 2026.

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: To get SEC approval on or before February 20th? If not we may get it later February or early March? Read the following and decide for yourselves...I'm not sure what to think? It would be nice others perspectives. ............................................ When an F-4/A (amendment to a foreign private issuer merger/exchange registration statement) is submitted to the SEC, the quickest it can generally become effective is immediately upon filing, provided the SEC has granted a request for acceleration of effectiveness. However, the practical timeline and requirements are as follows: Acceleration Request: If the amendment (F-4/A) resolves all previous SEC staff comments, the company will typically file a request for acceleration under Rule 461. The staff can declare the amendment effective shortly after filing, often within a few hours or on the same day, assuming the filing is processed. Automatic Effectiveness (No Delaying Amendment): If the F-4/A removes the "delaying amendment" (Rule 473) and includes specific language referencing Section 8(a), it can become effective automatically on the 20th calendar day after filing. Without Acceleration: If a new F-4/A is filed and it does not request acceleration, the 20-day waiting period generally restarts from the date of that amendment. Key Considerations: Filing Deadline: To be considered for same-day or accelerated processing, the F-4/A should generally be filed on EDGAR before 5:30 p.m. ET. Target Requirement: For F-4 business combinations, the prospectus must be sent to security holders at least 20 business days before the meeting or consummation of the transaction. Disclaimer: SEC registration statement effectiveness depends on specific staff review, and timelines can vary based on the complexity of the filing and the nature of the amendments. data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Reading the recent Bangladesh related news in isolation misses the point. When you put it together, the picture is much clearer. Fact 1 bKash has already processed 5 million inbound remittance transactions in 10 months, settled via Pubali Bank PLC, across 33 countries and 11 international MTOs, with instant wallet credit and government FX incentives so proven national scale infrastructure https://www.thedailystar.net/business/organisation-news/news/bkash-sees-50-lakh-remittance-transfers-through-pubali-bank-10 Fact 2 The bank and bKash went fully 24/7 with automated cash and liquidity management for agents and distributors. We now have always on settlement, real-time liquidity, and no banking cutoffs. Pubali is clearly acting as the core settlement and liquidity bank behind bKash. Fact 3 We confirmed our  collaboration goes live next week giving real-time disbursement into bKash wallets, wallet-to-wallet remittance, fee share plus FX income targeting 900,000 Bangladeshi workers in Malaysia .. 37% of foreign workers. At the time of the RNS, the question was whether this could scale. With bKash already settling millions of remittances via Pubali, and liquidity now running 24/7 that question is effectively answered in today’s news. We ain’t building new rails in Bangladesh we are plugging into an existing, regulated, alwayson digital money system that’s already operating at scale. We don’t need a RNS naming a settlement bank becauseCorrespondent and liquidity banks don’t get headline mentions, they run the infrastructure and Pubali is already doing that job for bKash. The board’s comment about near-term revenues being “modest” is sensible caution and the risk profile has shifted to proven settlement at scale,24/7 liquidity, fees and FX participation, zero infrastructure rebuild. All to play for

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: MXD, for the first time in over 200 posts you’ve actually put something on the table that can be discussed rather than reacted to with an emoji. That’s a step in the right direction, and credit where it’s due. Opinions are exactly that, opinions, and when they’re grounded in something tangible, they can be debated. So, let’s go through your points, because there is substance in parts of it, but the framing is doing a lot of heavy lifting. 1. Volatility Yes, MBO is volatile. It’s AIM, volatility is the entry fee, not a plot twist. The same mechanism that gave you a -40% swing last week is the one that gave you +40% today. If that’s “analysis”, then the bar really has been on the floor. 2. Negative equity / working capital You’ve dressed this up like a red siren, but settlement based fintech’s often show negative equity because of timing windows, money in transit, float obligations, settlement cycles. It’s accounting mechanics, not a death rattle. But sure, it sounds dramatic when you frame it that way. 3. Debt levels Debt to equity ratios become meaningless when equity is temporarily negative. It inflates the number into something monstrous. The real question is whether obligations are being serviced. 4. Insider ownership High insider ownership reduces liquidity, yes, but it also means the people running the business actually care about the outcome. It’s not inherently negative unless you’re trying to make it sound like a Bond villain subplot. 5. Regulatory exposure Fair point, but Malaysia is one of the more stable fintech regulatory environments in ASEAN. The Bangladesh corridor has more moving parts, but that’s also where the upside sits. You can’t have corridor based growth without corridor based regulation. That’s how corridors work. 6. “Speculative nature” Every early stage fintech corridor play is speculative until the rails go live. That’s why 15 Feb matters; it’s the moment the business moves from potential to operational. After that, speculation becomes data. What your analysis is missing entirely You’ve listed the risks, fine. But investment is risk vs reward, and you’ve only covered the half that lets you use dramatic wording. The reward side includes: •	the Malaysia - Bangladesh corridor •	real time wallet disbursement •	fee share + FX income •	integration into the bKash ecosystem •	ecosystem upgrades like Pubali Bank improving the receiving rail •	regulatory approvals already secured You can’t analyse MBO purely through historical financials. You analyse it through future cashflows and corridor scalability, otherwise you’re just reading numbers out loud. So yes, MXD, credit where it’s due. For the first time in 200+ posts, you’ve produced something that can actually be discussed rather than scrolled past.

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: We listed in 2007 with 94m shares. Fast forward to today, Feb 4th 2026 and the share count is 106m That’s a net increase of 12m shares in 19 years !!!!! Total dilution is around 12.8% since admission Annualised dilution 0.6–0.7% per year Just Let that sink in for a moment Most AIM companies manage that level of dilution in 12 to 18 months, not over two decades. All of this is visible in the original admission document and today’s information https://www.mobilityone.com.my/v7/admission-report.html For an AIM listed fintech/payments business, or in fact any type of business this level of capital discipline is exceptionally rare, in fact I would love to see a chart which shows this type of information and statistics! According to a Grant Thornton, 75% of all funds raised by AIM companies since 2007 have been through secondary issues. I've only ever really looked at this since you mentioned the shares held by the BOD (which I've always known is very high)  so thanks for pointing that out mxd, very good spot!!

data.author: StockMaiden
data.content: It’s important to note that: No revenue or earnings are expected from the new Islamic banking business in 2026, it’s a long-lead, future project. Also, for the full year ended 31 December 2024, MobilityOne reported a net loss of about £3.45 million after tax, meaning it did not make a profit for that year. For the first half of 2025 (six months to 30 June), it also recorded a loss after tax of £1.14 million, though this was smaller than the loss in the same period the previous year. Profitability is the challenge: Costs, such as administrative expenses, cost of sales, and associated company losses, have kept the company in the red. Although what can be seen encouraging is the revenue of £230.2m, however, the company is still in the loss and that's a red flag. It's actually quite worrying that they are not in profit despite having £203M of revenue. These guys had near 20 years in the business but still failed to make a profit. For that reason I have rated this a sell. Whether that will change further down the line would depend on if they can reduce expenses and admin costs. I would also like to point out that the Islamic finance is just a conditional approval for an Islamic digital banking arm in Labuan, Malaysia. It means that the operation are mostly limited to Malaysia.

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: The bullish engulfing pattern is a two-candle pattern used in technical analysis to predict the reversal of a downtrend. It suggests that buyers are taking control of the market from sellers. Here's a breakdown of how it works: Downtrend Precedence: The pattern appears at the end of a downtrend. Two Candlesticks: It consists of two candlesticks. The first is a small bearish (red or black) candlestick. The second is a large bullish (white or green) candlestick that completely "engulfs" the body of the previous candle. Market Sentiment Shift: The bullish engulfing pattern indicates a short-term change in market sentiment, potentially triggered by news, events, or price adjustments. Confirmation: To confirm the reversal, traders often look for a third bullish candlestick closing above the high of the engulfing candle. This suggests sustained upward momentum

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: Reasons for the Extension Amendment Proposal TETE has determined that there will not be sufficient time before February 20, 2026 (its current termination date) to hold an Extraordinary General Meeting to obtain the requisite shareholder approval of, and to consummate, a Business Combination. The Articles of Association currently provide that TETE has until the Termination Date to complete an initial business combination. TETE and its officers and directors agreed that they would not seek to amend the Articles of Association to allow for a longer period of time to complete a business combination unless TETE provided holders of its Public Shares with the right to seek redemption of their Public Shares in connection therewith. While TETE is using its best efforts to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date, the Board believes that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that the Extension be obtained so that, in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not able to be consummated on or before the Termination Date, TETE will have an additional amount of time to consummate a Business Combination. Without the Extension, TETE believes that there is significant risk that TETE will not, despite its best efforts, be able to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date. If that were to occur, TETE would be precluded from completing a Business Combination and would be forced to liquidate even if TETE shareholders are otherwise in favor of consummating a Business Combination. The Extension Amendment Proposal is essential to allowing TETE additional time to consummate a Business Combination in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not completed on or before the Termination Date. Approval of each of the Extension Amendment Proposal and the Trust Agreement Amendment Proposal is a condition to the implementation of the Extension. TETE believes that given TETE’s expenditure of time, effort and money on a Business Combination, circumstances warrant ensuring that TETE is in the best position possible to consummate a Business Combination and that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that TETE obtain the Extension if needed. TETE believes a Business Combination will provide significant benefits to its shareholders. .............................................................................. After reading the above, if things do overrun into the extension period (hopefully not)......surely it wont be for too long? Certainly not August? All they need to do is arrange and conduct the EGM (shareholder approval), plus consummate the Business Combination. Does anyone have any idea how long the consummation takes to complete? It can't take too long if they were hoping/expecting to complete before 20th February! Lets hope they can squeeze everything i

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Here’s the reference in the 26th September RNS The Group expects further growth in the money transfer business with such growth expected to be fuelled by strategic partnerships and market diversification. “While development using SWIFT network is still underway, new collaborations with bKash (i.e, the biggest mobile financial services provider in Bangladesh) and Mastercard Send, which is expected to go live in the next few months, will enhance the Group's product offerings, enabling faster and more secure cross-border transactions.” Additionally, the Group has initiated incoming remittance services to Somalia, tapping into underserved markets and broadening its global reach. These initiatives are expected to drive revenue growth.”

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Very good point, Warrie  honestly didn’t even cross my mind about the wortk ethic. I’ve just gone back through a few RNSs this evening and I actually think we’re due another announcement fairly soon around Mastercard Send. It’s mentioned alongside bKash in the half year, so it feels like the next logical step? When you look at the recent bKash news in that context, it starts to make a lot more sense especially when you remember we’re doing £230 million in revenue and still losing money. That tells you straight away the issue here isn’t scale, it’s margin mix. The legacy business around airtime reloads and bill payments does huge volume, but at very thin margins, and to be fair the Board has been pretty open about that. Where it gets interesting now is what’s now being layered on top. bKash isn’t a concept or a pilot as shared in my original post, expats sent remittances more than five million times, settled instantly via Pubali. That corridor now runs 24/7, 365. The behaviour is already there and it’s trusted, it’s repeat usage at scale, and as you mentioned, the working patterns and hours are very different to what most people are used to in the UK. We’re not trying to invent demand here. We’re plugging into an ecosystem where remittance is frequent, digital and increasingly stays inside the wallet for bills, payments and services which is exactly where fee income and FX margin live! The Board has been clear that remittance revenues will be “relatively modest”, and that makes total sense against a £230m revenue base. But the point isn’t headline growth anymore, it’s quality. At this scale, even a small improvement in blended margin has an outsized impact and roughly speaking, a 1% uplift in margin is worth north of £2 million The strategy explicitly references Mastercard Send still to come. That’s not name dropping or hype. it’s better infrastructure with faster settlement, broader corridor reach, lower friction and better transaction velocity. You don’t add that unless the volumes already justify it, and in this case we  clearly do. The real question now is whether the economics on flows we already have can be steadily improved. If they can we just need better rails on existing, and very soon expanding, transaction volumes! Bodes well for the SPAC listing!

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Bangladeshi expatriates have sent remittances to local bKash accounts more than five million times within 10 months via Pubali Bank. This hassle-free and secure service, offered by the mobile financial service (MFS) provider bKash, has earned the trust of expatriates and their families, encouraging sending remittances through legal channels, strengthening the country’s foreign currency reserves. Recently, a ceremony was held at bKash’s headquarters to celebrate this achievement where Pubali Bank’s Managing Director and CEO Mohammad Ali and bKash’s CEO Kamal Quadir, along with senior officials from both organisations were present. They highlighted the significance of this joint service and pledged to make remittance services even easier and safer for users. As a vital lifeline for the country's economy, these hard-earned remittances from expatriates are boosting the country's foreign exchange reserves and contributing to macroeconomic stability. To facilitate this, Pubali Bank and bKash have created a robust ecosystem for expatriates, to send remittances easily and securely. Currently, expatriates from 33 countries can send remittances through 11 international Money Transfer Operators (MTOs), which are settled instantly in the recipient's bKash account through Pubali Bank. Besides, recipients receive a government incentive of Tk 25 per thousand. They can easily cash out the remittance from nearby bKash agent points. Moreover, Families of the expatriates can utilise remittance to take various services through their bKash accounts, including paying for products and services, utility bills (gas, electricity, water), sending money, mobile recharge, paying educational and government fees, donations, insurance premiums, microfinance payments and many other services from the comfort of their homes. In addition to offering convenient, instant and secure remittance transfers, bKash has lowered cash-out fees. Beneficiaries can now withdraw remittances at a minimal cost of Tk 7 per thousand from approximately 2,500 ATMs of 19 leading commercial banks. December 2025 https://unb.com.bd/category/Press%20Releases/expats-send-remittance-over-5m-times-to-bkash-via-pubali-bank-in-10-month/174301

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: Key Factors for MBO collaboration with bKash: • The "Digital Conversion" Upside: Currently, over 40% of outward remittances from Malaysia are digital. MBO is targeting the remaining 60% who still use cash. • Network Synergy: bKash recently (Feb 2026) signed a deal with Pubali Bank for 24/7 automated cash management. While independent of MBO, this strengthens the bKash ecosystem's liquidity, making the "receiving" end more attractive for MBO's customers. • User Base: With ~900,000 Bangladeshi permit holders in Malaysia, even capturing a 5–10% market share of this specific corridor would represent a significant volume for a company of MBO's size (Market Cap ~£6m). Since the service launches on Feb 15, the first meaningful data on transaction volumes will likely start appearing in quarterly updates around May or June 2026.

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: To get SEC approval on or before February 20th? If not we may get it later February or early March? Read the following and decide for yourselves...I'm not sure what to think? It would be nice others perspectives. ............................................ When an F-4/A (amendment to a foreign private issuer merger/exchange registration statement) is submitted to the SEC, the quickest it can generally become effective is immediately upon filing, provided the SEC has granted a request for acceleration of effectiveness. However, the practical timeline and requirements are as follows: Acceleration Request: If the amendment (F-4/A) resolves all previous SEC staff comments, the company will typically file a request for acceleration under Rule 461. The staff can declare the amendment effective shortly after filing, often within a few hours or on the same day, assuming the filing is processed. Automatic Effectiveness (No Delaying Amendment): If the F-4/A removes the "delaying amendment" (Rule 473) and includes specific language referencing Section 8(a), it can become effective automatically on the 20th calendar day after filing. Without Acceleration: If a new F-4/A is filed and it does not request acceleration, the 20-day waiting period generally restarts from the date of that amendment. Key Considerations: Filing Deadline: To be considered for same-day or accelerated processing, the F-4/A should generally be filed on EDGAR before 5:30 p.m. ET. Target Requirement: For F-4 business combinations, the prospectus must be sent to security holders at least 20 business days before the meeting or consummation of the transaction. Disclaimer: SEC registration statement effectiveness depends on specific staff review, and timelines can vary based on the complexity of the filing and the nature of the amendments. data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Reading the recent Bangladesh related news in isolation misses the point. When you put it together, the picture is much clearer. Fact 1 bKash has already processed 5 million inbound remittance transactions in 10 months, settled via Pubali Bank PLC, across 33 countries and 11 international MTOs, with instant wallet credit and government FX incentives so proven national scale infrastructure https://www.thedailystar.net/business/organisation-news/news/bkash-sees-50-lakh-remittance-transfers-through-pubali-bank-10 Fact 2 The bank and bKash went fully 24/7 with automated cash and liquidity management for agents and distributors. We now have always on settlement, real-time liquidity, and no banking cutoffs. Pubali is clearly acting as the core settlement and liquidity bank behind bKash. Fact 3 We confirmed our  collaboration goes live next week giving real-time disbursement into bKash wallets, wallet-to-wallet remittance, fee share plus FX income targeting 900,000 Bangladeshi workers in Malaysia .. 37% of foreign workers. At the time of the RNS, the question was whether this could scale. With bKash already settling millions of remittances via Pubali, and liquidity now running 24/7 that question is effectively answered in today’s news. We ain’t building new rails in Bangladesh we are plugging into an existing, regulated, alwayson digital money system that’s already operating at scale. We don’t need a RNS naming a settlement bank becauseCorrespondent and liquidity banks don’t get headline mentions, they run the infrastructure and Pubali is already doing that job for bKash. The board’s comment about near-term revenues being “modest” is sensible caution and the risk profile has shifted to proven settlement at scale,24/7 liquidity, fees and FX participation, zero infrastructure rebuild. All to play for

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: MXD, for the first time in over 200 posts you’ve actually put something on the table that can be discussed rather than reacted to with an emoji. That’s a step in the right direction, and credit where it’s due. Opinions are exactly that, opinions, and when they’re grounded in something tangible, they can be debated. So, let’s go through your points, because there is substance in parts of it, but the framing is doing a lot of heavy lifting. 1. Volatility Yes, MBO is volatile. It’s AIM, volatility is the entry fee, not a plot twist. The same mechanism that gave you a -40% swing last week is the one that gave you +40% today. If that’s “analysis”, then the bar really has been on the floor. 2. Negative equity / working capital You’ve dressed this up like a red siren, but settlement based fintech’s often show negative equity because of timing windows, money in transit, float obligations, settlement cycles. It’s accounting mechanics, not a death rattle. But sure, it sounds dramatic when you frame it that way. 3. Debt levels Debt to equity ratios become meaningless when equity is temporarily negative. It inflates the number into something monstrous. The real question is whether obligations are being serviced. 4. Insider ownership High insider ownership reduces liquidity, yes, but it also means the people running the business actually care about the outcome. It’s not inherently negative unless you’re trying to make it sound like a Bond villain subplot. 5. Regulatory exposure Fair point, but Malaysia is one of the more stable fintech regulatory environments in ASEAN. The Bangladesh corridor has more moving parts, but that’s also where the upside sits. You can’t have corridor based growth without corridor based regulation. That’s how corridors work. 6. “Speculative nature” Every early stage fintech corridor play is speculative until the rails go live. That’s why 15 Feb matters; it’s the moment the business moves from potential to operational. After that, speculation becomes data. What your analysis is missing entirely You’ve listed the risks, fine. But investment is risk vs reward, and you’ve only covered the half that lets you use dramatic wording. The reward side includes: •	the Malaysia - Bangladesh corridor •	real time wallet disbursement •	fee share + FX income •	integration into the bKash ecosystem •	ecosystem upgrades like Pubali Bank improving the receiving rail •	regulatory approvals already secured You can’t analyse MBO purely through historical financials. You analyse it through future cashflows and corridor scalability, otherwise you’re just reading numbers out loud. So yes, MXD, credit where it’s due. For the first time in 200+ posts, you’ve produced something that can actually be discussed rather than scrolled past.

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: We listed in 2007 with 94m shares. Fast forward to today, Feb 4th 2026 and the share count is 106m That’s a net increase of 12m shares in 19 years !!!!! Total dilution is around 12.8% since admission Annualised dilution 0.6–0.7% per year Just Let that sink in for a moment Most AIM companies manage that level of dilution in 12 to 18 months, not over two decades. All of this is visible in the original admission document and today’s information https://www.mobilityone.com.my/v7/admission-report.html For an AIM listed fintech/payments business, or in fact any type of business this level of capital discipline is exceptionally rare, in fact I would love to see a chart which shows this type of information and statistics! According to a Grant Thornton, 75% of all funds raised by AIM companies since 2007 have been through secondary issues. I've only ever really looked at this since you mentioned the shares held by the BOD (which I've always known is very high)  so thanks for pointing that out mxd, very good spot!!

data.author: StockMaiden
data.content: It’s important to note that: No revenue or earnings are expected from the new Islamic banking business in 2026, it’s a long-lead, future project. Also, for the full year ended 31 December 2024, MobilityOne reported a net loss of about £3.45 million after tax, meaning it did not make a profit for that year. For the first half of 2025 (six months to 30 June), it also recorded a loss after tax of £1.14 million, though this was smaller than the loss in the same period the previous year. Profitability is the challenge: Costs, such as administrative expenses, cost of sales, and associated company losses, have kept the company in the red. Although what can be seen encouraging is the revenue of £230.2m, however, the company is still in the loss and that's a red flag. It's actually quite worrying that they are not in profit despite having £203M of revenue. These guys had near 20 years in the business but still failed to make a profit. For that reason I have rated this a sell. Whether that will change further down the line would depend on if they can reduce expenses and admin costs. I would also like to point out that the Islamic finance is just a conditional approval for an Islamic digital banking arm in Labuan, Malaysia. It means that the operation are mostly limited to Malaysia.

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: The bullish engulfing pattern is a two-candle pattern used in technical analysis to predict the reversal of a downtrend. It suggests that buyers are taking control of the market from sellers. Here's a breakdown of how it works: Downtrend Precedence: The pattern appears at the end of a downtrend. Two Candlesticks: It consists of two candlesticks. The first is a small bearish (red or black) candlestick. The second is a large bullish (white or green) candlestick that completely "engulfs" the body of the previous candle. Market Sentiment Shift: The bullish engulfing pattern indicates a short-term change in market sentiment, potentially triggered by news, events, or price adjustments. Confirmation: To confirm the reversal, traders often look for a third bullish candlestick closing above the high of the engulfing candle. This suggests sustained upward momentum

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: Reasons for the Extension Amendment Proposal TETE has determined that there will not be sufficient time before February 20, 2026 (its current termination date) to hold an Extraordinary General Meeting to obtain the requisite shareholder approval of, and to consummate, a Business Combination. The Articles of Association currently provide that TETE has until the Termination Date to complete an initial business combination. TETE and its officers and directors agreed that they would not seek to amend the Articles of Association to allow for a longer period of time to complete a business combination unless TETE provided holders of its Public Shares with the right to seek redemption of their Public Shares in connection therewith. While TETE is using its best efforts to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date, the Board believes that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that the Extension be obtained so that, in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not able to be consummated on or before the Termination Date, TETE will have an additional amount of time to consummate a Business Combination. Without the Extension, TETE believes that there is significant risk that TETE will not, despite its best efforts, be able to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date. If that were to occur, TETE would be precluded from completing a Business Combination and would be forced to liquidate even if TETE shareholders are otherwise in favor of consummating a Business Combination. The Extension Amendment Proposal is essential to allowing TETE additional time to consummate a Business Combination in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not completed on or before the Termination Date. Approval of each of the Extension Amendment Proposal and the Trust Agreement Amendment Proposal is a condition to the implementation of the Extension. TETE believes that given TETE’s expenditure of time, effort and money on a Business Combination, circumstances warrant ensuring that TETE is in the best position possible to consummate a Business Combination and that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that TETE obtain the Extension if needed. TETE believes a Business Combination will provide significant benefits to its shareholders. .............................................................................. After reading the above, if things do overrun into the extension period (hopefully not)......surely it wont be for too long? Certainly not August? All they need to do is arrange and conduct the EGM (shareholder approval), plus consummate the Business Combination. Does anyone have any idea how long the consummation takes to complete? It can't take too long if they were hoping/expecting to complete before 20th February! Lets hope they can squeeze everything i

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: If you’re going to present yourself as an authority on MBO (150 posts in the last 30 days), the basics need to be accurate. You’re mixing up two completely separate things: 1. TETE’s AGM extension - That’s a corporate admin item on their side. It has no bearing on MBO’s regulatory approvals, corridor readiness, or operational sequencing. 2. MBO’s operational catalysts - These are driven by the corridor infrastructure, not by a merger vote in another entity.  The near‑term milestones are: •	receiving‑side banking alignment on 15 Feb •	corridor activation •	first settlement cycle •	initial revenue recognition These are all verifiable from prior disclosures and partner‑side sequencing. If you want to contribute meaningfully to the board, the distinction between external corporate timelines and MBO’s operational execution is the starting point. Presenting them as the same thing only misleads people who haven’t done the research.

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: There’s been some confusion on the board about what constitutes meaningful near‑term events for MBO, so here’s a clearer, verifiable breakdown of what actually matters from an operational and regulatory standpoint. The TETE AGM on 20 February relates to their own corporate timetable for a long‑running transaction window. It does not alter MBO’s regulatory approvals, corridor readiness, or operational sequencing. These are separate entities with separate processes. For MBO specifically, the short‑term catalysts are operational and can be verified against prior RNS disclosures, partner statements, and regulatory approvals already granted. Receiving‑Side Banking Upgrade (15 February Window) The receiving‑side infrastructure upgrade completes on 15 February, which aligns with the operational window previously referenced by partners. This is a standard prerequisite step before a corridor moves from “ready” to “active,” ensuring settlement, reconciliation, and wallet disbursement systems are fully aligned. Corridor Activation (Operational Go‑Live) This is the primary near‑term milestone. Once the Malaysia -Bangladesh corridor is activated, the system transitions from framework to execution. What can be verified: •	Regulatory approvals on both ends have already been disclosed. •	Integration with the receiving ecosystem (including wallet disbursement capability) has been confirmed. •	Settlement mechanics have been defined in previous communications. •	The remaining step is operational switch‑on. First Settlement Cycle The first completed settlement cycle is a technical confirmation that the rails are functioning end to end. What can be verified: •	Settlement windows and float mechanics were previously outlined. •	The infrastructure for cross border settlement is already in place. •	This step follows immediately after activation. Initial Revenue Recognition Even modest early revenue is meaningful because it confirms the commercial model is functioning. What can be verified: •	The revenue model (fee share + FX) has been described in prior disclosures. •	Revenue begins only once transactions are flowing. •	This is the first hard data point the market will receive post activation. Volume Indicators and Throughput Guidance Directional commentary on expected volumes is a key short term indicator. What can be verified: •	Partner driven volumes are typically disclosed after initial operational bedding in. •	Early adoption signals often follow shortly after go live. •	This is standard sequencing for corridor based fintech operations. Additional Corridor or Partner Updates Once the first corridor is live, expansion becomes the natural next step. What can be verified: •	The company has previously referenced multi corridor ambitions. •	Additional partnerships typically follow once the first corridor is proven operationally.

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: You’re talking about the TETE AGM, which is a separate corporate process. Extensions on that side don’t change the operational position MBO is in. The short‑term items for MBO are operational, corridor activation, settlement flow, and revenue recognition, not governance steps relating to TETE’s own timetable. The AGM vote you’ve linked is about extending a long‑running transaction window on their side. It doesn’t alter the mechanics, regulatory approvals, or operational readiness of the Malaysia, Bangladesh corridor. That’s why the market is watching for operational confirmation rather than administrative extensions. Different entities, different processes, different timelines.

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Here’s the reference in the 26th September RNS The Group expects further growth in the money transfer business with such growth expected to be fuelled by strategic partnerships and market diversification. “While development using SWIFT network is still underway, new collaborations with bKash (i.e, the biggest mobile financial services provider in Bangladesh) and Mastercard Send, which is expected to go live in the next few months, will enhance the Group's product offerings, enabling faster and more secure cross-border transactions.” Additionally, the Group has initiated incoming remittance services to Somalia, tapping into underserved markets and broadening its global reach. These initiatives are expected to drive revenue growth.”

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Very good point, Warrie  honestly didn’t even cross my mind about the wortk ethic. I’ve just gone back through a few RNSs this evening and I actually think we’re due another announcement fairly soon around Mastercard Send. It’s mentioned alongside bKash in the half year, so it feels like the next logical step? When you look at the recent bKash news in that context, it starts to make a lot more sense especially when you remember we’re doing £230 million in revenue and still losing money. That tells you straight away the issue here isn’t scale, it’s margin mix. The legacy business around airtime reloads and bill payments does huge volume, but at very thin margins, and to be fair the Board has been pretty open about that. Where it gets interesting now is what’s now being layered on top. bKash isn’t a concept or a pilot as shared in my original post, expats sent remittances more than five million times, settled instantly via Pubali. That corridor now runs 24/7, 365. The behaviour is already there and it’s trusted, it’s repeat usage at scale, and as you mentioned, the working patterns and hours are very different to what most people are used to in the UK. We’re not trying to invent demand here. We’re plugging into an ecosystem where remittance is frequent, digital and increasingly stays inside the wallet for bills, payments and services which is exactly where fee income and FX margin live! The Board has been clear that remittance revenues will be “relatively modest”, and that makes total sense against a £230m revenue base. But the point isn’t headline growth anymore, it’s quality. At this scale, even a small improvement in blended margin has an outsized impact and roughly speaking, a 1% uplift in margin is worth north of £2 million The strategy explicitly references Mastercard Send still to come. That’s not name dropping or hype. it’s better infrastructure with faster settlement, broader corridor reach, lower friction and better transaction velocity. You don’t add that unless the volumes already justify it, and in this case we  clearly do. The real question now is whether the economics on flows we already have can be steadily improved. If they can we just need better rails on existing, and very soon expanding, transaction volumes! Bodes well for the SPAC listing!

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Bangladeshi expatriates have sent remittances to local bKash accounts more than five million times within 10 months via Pubali Bank. This hassle-free and secure service, offered by the mobile financial service (MFS) provider bKash, has earned the trust of expatriates and their families, encouraging sending remittances through legal channels, strengthening the country’s foreign currency reserves. Recently, a ceremony was held at bKash’s headquarters to celebrate this achievement where Pubali Bank’s Managing Director and CEO Mohammad Ali and bKash’s CEO Kamal Quadir, along with senior officials from both organisations were present. They highlighted the significance of this joint service and pledged to make remittance services even easier and safer for users. As a vital lifeline for the country's economy, these hard-earned remittances from expatriates are boosting the country's foreign exchange reserves and contributing to macroeconomic stability. To facilitate this, Pubali Bank and bKash have created a robust ecosystem for expatriates, to send remittances easily and securely. Currently, expatriates from 33 countries can send remittances through 11 international Money Transfer Operators (MTOs), which are settled instantly in the recipient's bKash account through Pubali Bank. Besides, recipients receive a government incentive of Tk 25 per thousand. They can easily cash out the remittance from nearby bKash agent points. Moreover, Families of the expatriates can utilise remittance to take various services through their bKash accounts, including paying for products and services, utility bills (gas, electricity, water), sending money, mobile recharge, paying educational and government fees, donations, insurance premiums, microfinance payments and many other services from the comfort of their homes. In addition to offering convenient, instant and secure remittance transfers, bKash has lowered cash-out fees. Beneficiaries can now withdraw remittances at a minimal cost of Tk 7 per thousand from approximately 2,500 ATMs of 19 leading commercial banks. December 2025 https://unb.com.bd/category/Press%20Releases/expats-send-remittance-over-5m-times-to-bkash-via-pubali-bank-in-10-month/174301

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: Key Factors for MBO collaboration with bKash: • The "Digital Conversion" Upside: Currently, over 40% of outward remittances from Malaysia are digital. MBO is targeting the remaining 60% who still use cash. • Network Synergy: bKash recently (Feb 2026) signed a deal with Pubali Bank for 24/7 automated cash management. While independent of MBO, this strengthens the bKash ecosystem's liquidity, making the "receiving" end more attractive for MBO's customers. • User Base: With ~900,000 Bangladeshi permit holders in Malaysia, even capturing a 5–10% market share of this specific corridor would represent a significant volume for a company of MBO's size (Market Cap ~£6m). Since the service launches on Feb 15, the first meaningful data on transaction volumes will likely start appearing in quarterly updates around May or June 2026.

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: To get SEC approval on or before February 20th? If not we may get it later February or early March? Read the following and decide for yourselves...I'm not sure what to think? It would be nice others perspectives. ............................................ When an F-4/A (amendment to a foreign private issuer merger/exchange registration statement) is submitted to the SEC, the quickest it can generally become effective is immediately upon filing, provided the SEC has granted a request for acceleration of effectiveness. However, the practical timeline and requirements are as follows: Acceleration Request: If the amendment (F-4/A) resolves all previous SEC staff comments, the company will typically file a request for acceleration under Rule 461. The staff can declare the amendment effective shortly after filing, often within a few hours or on the same day, assuming the filing is processed. Automatic Effectiveness (No Delaying Amendment): If the F-4/A removes the "delaying amendment" (Rule 473) and includes specific language referencing Section 8(a), it can become effective automatically on the 20th calendar day after filing. Without Acceleration: If a new F-4/A is filed and it does not request acceleration, the 20-day waiting period generally restarts from the date of that amendment. Key Considerations: Filing Deadline: To be considered for same-day or accelerated processing, the F-4/A should generally be filed on EDGAR before 5:30 p.m. ET. Target Requirement: For F-4 business combinations, the prospectus must be sent to security holders at least 20 business days before the meeting or consummation of the transaction. Disclaimer: SEC registration statement effectiveness depends on specific staff review, and timelines can vary based on the complexity of the filing and the nature of the amendments. data.author: miningforgold
data.content: Reading the recent Bangladesh related news in isolation misses the point. When you put it together, the picture is much clearer. Fact 1 bKash has already processed 5 million inbound remittance transactions in 10 months, settled via Pubali Bank PLC, across 33 countries and 11 international MTOs, with instant wallet credit and government FX incentives so proven national scale infrastructure https://www.thedailystar.net/business/organisation-news/news/bkash-sees-50-lakh-remittance-transfers-through-pubali-bank-10 Fact 2 The bank and bKash went fully 24/7 with automated cash and liquidity management for agents and distributors. We now have always on settlement, real-time liquidity, and no banking cutoffs. Pubali is clearly acting as the core settlement and liquidity bank behind bKash. Fact 3 We confirmed our  collaboration goes live next week giving real-time disbursement into bKash wallets, wallet-to-wallet remittance, fee share plus FX income targeting 900,000 Bangladeshi workers in Malaysia .. 37% of foreign workers. At the time of the RNS, the question was whether this could scale. With bKash already settling millions of remittances via Pubali, and liquidity now running 24/7 that question is effectively answered in today’s news. We ain’t building new rails in Bangladesh we are plugging into an existing, regulated, alwayson digital money system that’s already operating at scale. We don’t need a RNS naming a settlement bank becauseCorrespondent and liquidity banks don’t get headline mentions, they run the infrastructure and Pubali is already doing that job for bKash. The board’s comment about near-term revenues being “modest” is sensible caution and the risk profile has shifted to proven settlement at scale,24/7 liquidity, fees and FX participation, zero infrastructure rebuild. All to play for

data.author: Wealth1
data.content: MXD, for the first time in over 200 posts you’ve actually put something on the table that can be discussed rather than reacted to with an emoji. That’s a step in the right direction, and credit where it’s due. Opinions are exactly that, opinions, and when they’re grounded in something tangible, they can be debated. So, let’s go through your points, because there is substance in parts of it, but the framing is doing a lot of heavy lifting. 1. Volatility Yes, MBO is volatile. It’s AIM, volatility is the entry fee, not a plot twist. The same mechanism that gave you a -40% swing last week is the one that gave you +40% today. If that’s “analysis”, then the bar really has been on the floor. 2. Negative equity / working capital You’ve dressed this up like a red siren, but settlement based fintech’s often show negative equity because of timing windows, money in transit, float obligations, settlement cycles. It’s accounting mechanics, not a death rattle. But sure, it sounds dramatic when you frame it that way. 3. Debt levels Debt to equity ratios become meaningless when equity is temporarily negative. It inflates the number into something monstrous. The real question is whether obligations are being serviced. 4. Insider ownership High insider ownership reduces liquidity, yes, but it also means the people running the business actually care about the outcome. It’s not inherently negative unless you’re trying to make it sound like a Bond villain subplot. 5. Regulatory exposure Fair point, but Malaysia is one of the more stable fintech regulatory environments in ASEAN. The Bangladesh corridor has more moving parts, but that’s also where the upside sits. You can’t have corridor based growth without corridor based regulation. That’s how corridors work. 6. “Speculative nature” Every early stage fintech corridor play is speculative until the rails go live. That’s why 15 Feb matters; it’s the moment the business moves from potential to operational. After that, speculation becomes data. What your analysis is missing entirely You’ve listed the risks, fine. But investment is risk vs reward, and you’ve only covered the half that lets you use dramatic wording. The reward side includes: •	the Malaysia - Bangladesh corridor •	real time wallet disbursement •	fee share + FX income •	integration into the bKash ecosystem •	ecosystem upgrades like Pubali Bank improving the receiving rail •	regulatory approvals already secured You can’t analyse MBO purely through historical financials. You analyse it through future cashflows and corridor scalability, otherwise you’re just reading numbers out loud. So yes, MXD, credit where it’s due. For the first time in 200+ posts, you’ve produced something that can actually be discussed rather than scrolled past.

data.author: miningforgold
data.content: We listed in 2007 with 94m shares. Fast forward to today, Feb 4th 2026 and the share count is 106m That’s a net increase of 12m shares in 19 years !!!!! Total dilution is around 12.8% since admission Annualised dilution 0.6–0.7% per year Just Let that sink in for a moment Most AIM companies manage that level of dilution in 12 to 18 months, not over two decades. All of this is visible in the original admission document and today’s information https://www.mobilityone.com.my/v7/admission-report.html For an AIM listed fintech/payments business, or in fact any type of business this level of capital discipline is exceptionally rare, in fact I would love to see a chart which shows this type of information and statistics! According to a Grant Thornton, 75% of all funds raised by AIM companies since 2007 have been through secondary issues. I've only ever really looked at this since you mentioned the shares held by the BOD (which I've always known is very high)  so thanks for pointing that out mxd, very good spot!!

data.author: StockMaiden
data.content: It’s important to note that: No revenue or earnings are expected from the new Islamic banking business in 2026, it’s a long-lead, future project. Also, for the full year ended 31 December 2024, MobilityOne reported a net loss of about £3.45 million after tax, meaning it did not make a profit for that year. For the first half of 2025 (six months to 30 June), it also recorded a loss after tax of £1.14 million, though this was smaller than the loss in the same period the previous year. Profitability is the challenge: Costs, such as administrative expenses, cost of sales, and associated company losses, have kept the company in the red. Although what can be seen encouraging is the revenue of £230.2m, however, the company is still in the loss and that's a red flag. It's actually quite worrying that they are not in profit despite having £203M of revenue. These guys had near 20 years in the business but still failed to make a profit. For that reason I have rated this a sell. Whether that will change further down the line would depend on if they can reduce expenses and admin costs. I would also like to point out that the Islamic finance is just a conditional approval for an Islamic digital banking arm in Labuan, Malaysia. It means that the operation are mostly limited to Malaysia.

data.author: onlyprofit
data.content: The bullish engulfing pattern is a two-candle pattern used in technical analysis to predict the reversal of a downtrend. It suggests that buyers are taking control of the market from sellers. Here's a breakdown of how it works: Downtrend Precedence: The pattern appears at the end of a downtrend. Two Candlesticks: It consists of two candlesticks. The first is a small bearish (red or black) candlestick. The second is a large bullish (white or green) candlestick that completely "engulfs" the body of the previous candle. Market Sentiment Shift: The bullish engulfing pattern indicates a short-term change in market sentiment, potentially triggered by news, events, or price adjustments. Confirmation: To confirm the reversal, traders often look for a third bullish candlestick closing above the high of the engulfing candle. This suggests sustained upward momentum

data.author: Stay.calm
data.content: Reasons for the Extension Amendment Proposal TETE has determined that there will not be sufficient time before February 20, 2026 (its current termination date) to hold an Extraordinary General Meeting to obtain the requisite shareholder approval of, and to consummate, a Business Combination. The Articles of Association currently provide that TETE has until the Termination Date to complete an initial business combination. TETE and its officers and directors agreed that they would not seek to amend the Articles of Association to allow for a longer period of time to complete a business combination unless TETE provided holders of its Public Shares with the right to seek redemption of their Public Shares in connection therewith. While TETE is using its best efforts to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date, the Board believes that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that the Extension be obtained so that, in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not able to be consummated on or before the Termination Date, TETE will have an additional amount of time to consummate a Business Combination. Without the Extension, TETE believes that there is significant risk that TETE will not, despite its best efforts, be able to complete a Business Combination on or before the Termination Date. If that were to occur, TETE would be precluded from completing a Business Combination and would be forced to liquidate even if TETE shareholders are otherwise in favor of consummating a Business Combination. The Extension Amendment Proposal is essential to allowing TETE additional time to consummate a Business Combination in the event a Business Combination is for any reason not completed on or before the Termination Date. Approval of each of the Extension Amendment Proposal and the Trust Agreement Amendment Proposal is a condition to the implementation of the Extension. TETE believes that given TETE’s expenditure of time, effort and money on a Business Combination, circumstances warrant ensuring that TETE is in the best position possible to consummate a Business Combination and that it is in the best interests of TETE shareholders that TETE obtain the Extension if needed. TETE believes a Business Combination will provide significant benefits to its shareholders. .............................................................................. After reading the above, if things do overrun into the extension period (hopefully not)......surely it wont be for too long? Certainly not August? All they need to do is arrange and conduct the EGM (shareholder approval), plus consummate the Business Combination. Does anyone have any idea how long the consummation takes to complete? It can't take too long if they were hoping/expecting to complete before 20th February! Lets hope they can squeeze everything i

company_30s.what_they_do: MBO.L focuses on mobile banking and digital money transfer services, partnering with regional fintechs to provide mobile wallets and cross‑border payments.
company_30s.why_they_matter: The company taps into a growing digital‑banking market in emerging economies, where mobile money usage is rising faster than traditional banking penetration.
company_30s.current_state: MBO.L is in a consolidation phase, having recently announced a partnership with bKash and awaiting regulatory approvals. The business is still early in its revenue generation journey but has begun to secure key contracts.

rns_narrative: The latest filings show the firm has secured a mobile‑money transfer collaboration with bKash, signalling a move toward commercial operations.
Regulatory updates, including a conditional approval for an Islamic digital banking licence, suggest that the company is clearing compliance hurdles.
Other announcements focus on partnership updates and the release of interim financials, indicating that MBO.L is working to stabilize its operations after a period of uncertainty.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Radio silence – no social chatter or news buzz.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bullish chatter yet – the market is largely unaware of the partnership moves.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Pessimism remains high because of the lack of visible traction, but the recent regulatory and partnership news could shift sentiment.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: From complete apathy toward a potential surprise if the partnership or licence is approved.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends is flat – no public interest spikes, meaning a news event could produce a sharp reaction.

near_term_catalysts: Approval of the Islamic digital banking licence, which would unlock new revenue streams.
Official launch of the mobile‑money transfer service with bKash, likely to drive user adoption and top‑line growth.
A volume spike on the stock as traders react to the partnership announcement or regulatory clearance.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for a sudden increase in daily trading volume and a break above the recent resistance level. Also monitor short‑interest data for signs of covering.
expect_next.timing_regime: The company appears to be in a late‑stage washout; a catalyst could trigger a rapid turnaround for contrarian traders.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Speculative Long – the setup is still early but shows promise if catalysts materialise.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: If the partnership or licence is approved, the stock could rebound 50–70% from its current low, reflecting the historical bounce of green‑signal stocks. A 50% recovery would more than double the investment.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: If the partnership falls through or regulatory approval stalls, the price might stay flat or decline a modest 10–15%. The downside is limited because the company has already shed most weak hands.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Risk 15% downside versus potential 70% upside equals roughly a 1:4.7 risk‑to‑reward asymmetry.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter a small position (10–20% of the allocation) at the current price. Use a tight stop 10% below entry to protect against a false break. Add 25% more if volume confirms a move up.
playbook.if_watching: Hold cash until a clear catalyst appears: either regulatory approval or a launch announcement. Also wait for a volume spike that confirms a break above the recent resistance.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this opportunity if there are signs of financial distress or if the partnership appears unlikely to close.

ai_insights.bottom_line: MBO.L’s recent partnership and regulatory updates hint at a possible rebound, but the lack of visible traction keeps the play speculative – a cautious contrarian long with a 1:5 risk‑to‑reward profile.
